easy.title: Scientists Map Our Body's Hidden Sixth Sense
easy.summary: Scientists are working on an exciting project to map a special system in our bodies called interoception. This is like a hidden sixth sense that helps our brain know what's happening inside us. It tells our brain when we need to breathe, helps control our blood pressure, and even helps fight germs when we get sick. A famous scientist named Ardem Patapoutian, who won a Nobel Prize, is leading a team from two research centers. They received $14.2 million from the government to study this important system. Interoception works through special nerve cells that are spread throughout our body organs like the heart, lungs, and stomach. These cells send messages to our brain about what our body needs. Unlike our five main senses that help us see, hear, smell, taste, and touch things outside our body, interoception helps us feel what's happening inside. The scientists want to create a detailed map showing how these nerve cells connect to different organs. This will help doctors understand how our body stays healthy and how to treat diseases better.

background_read: Our bodies have amazing systems that work automatically to keep us healthy. We have five main senses we learn about in school: sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch. But scientists have discovered there's another important sense called interoception that works inside our body. This hidden sense helps our brain know what our organs need without us even thinking about it. It tells us when we're hungry, thirsty, or need to breathe. Scientists are now studying this system to understand how it helps keep us alive and healthy every day.

middle.title: Mapping the Body's Internal Communication Network
middle.summary: A groundbreaking $14.2 million research project led by Nobel laureate Ardem Patapoutian aims to create the first comprehensive atlas of interoception, the body's internal sensory system often described as a 'hidden sixth sense.' This collaborative effort between Scripps Research and the Allen Institute received funding through the NIH's Transformative Research Award program, which supports high-risk, high-reward scientific endeavors. Interoception represents the nervous system's ability to monitor and regulate internal bodily functions such as breathing, heart rate, digestion, and immune response. Unlike traditional senses that detect external stimuli, interoception involves complex neural networks distributed throughout internal organs including the heart, lungs, stomach, and kidneys. The research team, which includes experts in neuroscience, chemistry, and molecular genetics, plans to map the anatomical and molecular connections between sensory neurons and various organs over a five-year period. This ambitious project addresses a significant gap in scientific understanding, as interoceptive signals have proven difficult to study due to their complexity and the challenges of accessing internal neural pathways. The resulting atlas could revolutionize our understanding of brain-body communication and potentially lead to new treatments for conditions related to autonomic nervous system dysfunction. By combining advanced genomic analysis with detailed anatomical mapping, the researchers hope to uncover how the body maintains internal balance and responds to physiological changes.

background_read: Interoception represents one of the most fundamental yet understudied aspects of human physiology. While we commonly learn about the five external senses in school, the concept of internal sensing has existed in scientific literature for over a century but remained difficult to investigate. The autonomic nervous system, which controls involuntary functions, relies on interoceptive signals to maintain homeostasis - the body's internal balance. Previous research has shown that disruptions in interoception may contribute to various health conditions including anxiety disorders, digestive problems, and cardiovascular diseases. The NIH's Transformative Research Award program, established in 2009, specifically targets projects that challenge conventional scientific approaches and have potential for major breakthroughs. This particular study builds on Ardem Patapoutian's Nobel Prize-winning work on cellular sensors for external stimuli, now applying similar principles to internal sensing mechanisms. The collaboration between Scripps Research and the Allen Institute brings together complementary expertise in neuroscience, molecular biology, and large-scale data analysis necessary for such a complex mapping project.

high.title: Deconstructing Interoception: A Multimillion-Dollar Initiative to Map the Neural Architecture of Internal Sensation
high.summary: A consortium of distinguished researchers led by Nobel laureate Ardem Patapoutian has secured a $14.2 million Transformative Research Award from the National Institutes of Health to undertake an unprecedented mapping of the human body's interoceptive system. This ambitious five-year project, conducted through collaboration between Scripps Research and the Allen Institute, aims to construct the first comprehensive anatomical and molecular atlas of the neural pathways that constitute what scientists term our 'hidden sixth sense.' Interoception represents the neurophysiological process through which the central nervous system continuously monitors and integrates signals from internal organs to regulate homeostatic functions including cardiorespiratory activity, gastrointestinal processes, and immune responses. Unlike exteroceptive senses that process external environmental stimuli, interoception involves complex, distributed neural networks that operate largely outside conscious awareness. The research team, comprising experts in neuroscience, chemical biology, and molecular genetics, will employ advanced genomic sequencing, single-cell analysis, and neural tracing techniques to delineate the precise connectivity between sensory neurons and visceral organs. This investigation addresses a critical lacuna in neurobiological understanding, as interoceptive signaling has remained enigmatic due to the technical challenges of accessing deep-tissue neural circuits and the complexity of overlapping physiological signals. The resulting atlas promises to elucidate fundamental mechanisms of brain-body integration and potentially identify novel therapeutic targets for conditions involving autonomic dysregulation, such as certain anxiety disorders, functional gastrointestinal diseases, and cardiovascular pathologies. By bridging molecular neuroscience with systems physiology, this project exemplifies the transformative potential of interdisciplinary approaches in advancing biomedical science.

background_read: Interoception represents a fundamental yet poorly understood dimension of nervous system function that bridges neurobiology, physiology, and clinical medicine. The concept originated in early 20th-century neurophysiology but gained renewed interest with advances in neural imaging and molecular biology. Current understanding positions interoception as crucial for maintaining allostasis—the process of achieving stability through physiological change—and has implications for conditions ranging from psychosomatic disorders to metabolic diseases. The NIH's Transformative Research Award program, part of the Common Fund, specifically targets investigations that challenge existing paradigms and have potential for paradigm-shifting discoveries. This project builds substantially on Patapoutian's Nobel-winning research on mechanosensation, extending those principles to the internal milieu. The collaboration leverages Scripps Research's strengths in chemical biology and neuroscience with the Allen Institute's expertise in large-scale molecular characterization of neural circuits. Understanding interoceptive mechanisms has become increasingly relevant given emerging evidence linking interoceptive dysfunction to various clinical conditions, including anxiety disorders, irritable bowel syndrome, and certain cardiovascular diseases. This research sits at the intersection of multiple scientific disciplines, requiring integration of molecular, cellular, systems, and computational approaches to address fundamental questions about how the nervous system monitors and regulates internal bodily states.
Article_Structure: This article details a groundbreaking $14.2 million NIH-funded initiative to map the neural architecture of interoception. The main points emphasize creating the first comprehensive atlas of internal sensory pathways through collaborative research between Scripps and Allen Institute. The purpose extends beyond basic science to addressing fundamental gaps in understanding brain-body communication and potential clinical applications for autonomic disorders. Evidence evaluation reveals strong institutional backing through the NIH's Transformative Research Award and involvement of recognized experts, though the novel nature of the research means outcomes remain speculative. Author credibility is exceptional, featuring Nobel laureate Ardem Patapoutian and established investigators from prestigious institutions with proven track records in sensory neuroscience. The methodology employs cutting-edge techniques including genomic sequencing, single-cell analysis, and neural tracing in an interdisciplinary framework. Critical assessment acknowledges the project's ambitious scope and technical challenges but recognizes its potential for transformative insights into neural regulation of physiological functions and identification of new therapeutic targets.

zh.title: 科学家启动1420万美元项目绘制人体“隐藏第六感”图谱
zh.summary: 一支由诺贝尔奖得主阿德姆·帕塔普蒂安领导的科研团队获得了美国国立卫生研究院1420万美元的资助，旨在开展一项前所未有的研究——绘制人体内部感觉系统（即所谓的“隐藏第六感”）的详细图谱。这项为期五年的合作项目由斯克里普斯研究所和艾伦研究所共同承担，专注于研究被称为“内感受”的生理过程。内感受是神经系统持续监测和调节人体内部功能的重要机制，负责控制呼吸、心率、消化和免疫反应等自主生理活动。与传统五种感知外部环境的感觉不同，内感受通过分布在内脏器官中的复杂神经网络运作，这些神经信号大多在无意识层面进行处理。研究团队将运用先进的基因组测序、单细胞分析和神经追踪技术，详细绘制感觉神经元与心脏、肺部、胃肠道等内脏器官之间的连接图谱。这项研究填补了神经生物学领域的重要空白，因为内感受信号由于技术挑战和生理信号的复杂性而长期难以深入研究。最终绘制出的图谱有望揭示大脑与身体沟通的基本机制，并可能为治疗自主神经系统紊乱相关疾病（如某些焦虑症、功能性胃肠疾病和心血管疾病）提供新的治疗靶点。该项目代表了跨学科研究方法在推动生物医学科学发展方面的巨大潜力。
